articles.headline: Working All Day for the I.R.S.
articles.snippet: Sift through mounds of I.R.S. data and discover something you probably already knew: People who work pay the bulk of the taxes.
articles.abstract: Sift through mounds of I.R.S. data and discover something you probably already knew: People who work pay the bulk of the taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney is not alone. I thought Mr. Romney’s 13.9 percent federal tax rate would be hard to beat. But among the 400 Americans with the highest adjusted gross incomes in 2008, 30 of them paid less than 10 percent and another 101 paid less than 15 percent. And these people earned, on average, more than 10 times Mr. Romney’s $21.7 million — an average of $270.5 million each.

articles.headline: A Rate Sleuth Making Rental Car Companies Squirm
articles.snippet: An online booking engine called AutoSlash engenders something like revulsion from members of the auto rental industry.
articles.abstract: An online booking engine called AutoSlash engenders something like revulsion from members of the auto rental industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a perfect world, we would get the lowest price for everything we buy without having to lift a finger to hunt for the best deal.

articles.headline: Islamists’ Ideas on Democracy and Faith Face Test in Tunisia
articles.snippet: In an article he wrote before his death on Thursday, Mr. Shadid examined how a party shaped by repression hopes to act as a regional model after being voted into power in Tunisia.
articles.abstract: In an article he wrote before his death on Thursday, Mr. Shadid examined how a party shaped by repression hopes to act as a regional model after being voted into power in Tunisia.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported and written before Mr. Shadid’s death in Syria.

articles.headline: Side Effects of Diet Pill Still Concern Regulators
articles.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration said it was worried about possible heart problems and birth defects with Qnexa, a weight-loss drug.
articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration said it was worried about possible heart problems and birth defects with Qnexa, a weight-loss drug.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration continues to have concerns that a weight-loss drug it is reviewing for the second time can cause birth defects and heart problems, documents released by the agency on Friday show.

articles.headline: Drones Set Sights on U.S. Skies
articles.snippet: A new law will permit drones of all kinds in American airspace by 2015, which concerns privacy advocates who decry expanding surveillance boundaries.
articles.abstract: A new law will permit drones of all kinds in American airspace by 2015, which concerns privacy advocates who decry expanding surveillance boundaries.
articles.lead_paragraph: WOODLAND HILLS, Calif. — Daniel Gárate’s career came crashing to earth a few weeks ago. That’s when the Los Angeles Police Department warned local real estate agents not to hire photographers like Mr. Gárate, who was helping sell luxury property by using a drone to shoot sumptuous aerial movies. Flying drones for commercial purposes, the police said, violated federal aviation rules.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Somini Sengupta

articles.headline: Thinking Outside the Redbox
articles.snippet: Coinstar, the self-service retail business, prepares for the decline of movie rentals by experimenting with kiosks for products like coffee and electronics.
articles.abstract: Coinstar, the self-service retail business, prepares for the decline of movie rentals by experimenting with kiosks for products like coffee and electronics.
articles.lead_paragraph: BELLEVUE, Wash. — To many people, the coffee dispensed by vending machines is a sour brew, forever associated with jury duty waiting rooms and bowling alleys.

articles.headline: For Women Under 30, Most Births Occur Outside Marriage
articles.snippet: Motherhood without marriage among younger women across the country is both a symbol of the transforming family and a hint of coming generational change.
articles.abstract: Motherhood without marriage among younger women across the country is both a symbol of the transforming family and a hint of coming generational change.
articles.lead_paragraph: LORAIN, Ohio — It used to be called illegitimacy. Now it is the new normal. After steadily rising for five decades, the share of children born to unmarried women has crossed a threshold: more than half of births to American women under 30 occur outside marriage.
articles.byline: By Jason DeParle and Sabrina Tavernise

articles.headline: Rising Gas Prices Give G.O.P. Issue to Attack Obama
articles.snippet: The White House is preparing for Republicans to use the high cost of oil and gas to condemn the president’s policies on energy and the economy.
articles.abstract: The White House is preparing for Republicans to use the high cost of oil and gas to condemn the president’s policies on energy and the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rising gasoline prices, trumpeted in foot-tall numbers on street corners across the country, are causing concern among advisers to President Obama that a budding sense of economic optimism could be undermined just as he heads into the general election.

articles.headline: A Fog Warning, Again, for Municipal Bonds
articles.snippet: State and local entities all across the country issue municipal bonds, which are often their lifeblood. But not all are adapting well to a new, more open world.
articles.abstract: State and local entities all across the country issue municipal bonds, which are often their lifeblood. But not all are adapting well to a new, more open world.
articles.lead_paragraph: FEW areas of finance are as opaque as the municipal bond market.

articles.headline: Ford’s Mr. Inside, in Sight of the Crown
articles.snippet: Mark Fields is the heir apparent to Alan Mulally as C.E.O. of the resurgent Ford Motor Company — as long as there are no stumbles.
articles.abstract: Mark Fields is the heir apparent to Alan Mulally as C.E.O. of the resurgent Ford Motor Company — as long as there are no stumbles.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARK FIELDS should be feeling pretty good right about now.

articles.headline: In Alabama, a County That Fell Off the Financial Cliff
articles.snippet: Jefferson County, Ala., is drowning under $4 billion in debt, the result of a botched sewer project and corrupt business dealings.
articles.abstract: Jefferson County, Ala., is drowning under $4 billion in debt, the result of a botched sewer project and corrupt business dealings.
articles.lead_paragraph: ONE county jail here is so crowded that some inmates sleep on the floor, while the other county jail, a few miles down the road, sits empty.

articles.headline: South Africans Suffer as Graft Saps Provinces
articles.snippet: Officials in Limpopo Province overspent their budget by about $250 million, much of it on questionable or fraudulent payments and contracts with businesses linked to the province’s politicians.
articles.abstract: Officials in Limpopo Province overspent their budget by about $250 million, much of it on questionable or fraudulent payments and contracts with businesses linked to the province’s politicians.
articles.lead_paragraph: TSHIKOTA, South Africa — When she moved from a cramped room in a boardinghouse to her very own bungalow on a speck of land here last year, Jeanette Munyai became one of the millions of South Africans given a decent home by an ambitious government program inaugurated at the end of apartheid.

articles.headline: In the Tastes of Young Men, Humor Is Most Prized, a Survey Finds
articles.snippet: Research commissioned by Comedy Central shows that comedy has become more essential than “personal style” to how young men view themselves and others.
articles.abstract: Research commissioned by Comedy Central shows that comedy has become more essential than “personal style” to how young men view themselves and others.
articles.lead_paragraph: Comedy Central has a lot riding on, well, comedy. And now research it commissioned about how young men view humor has provided the cable channel with some encouraging conclusions about the preferences of its most important demographic group.

articles.headline: Using Rap to Teach Pithy Lessons in Business
articles.snippet: Ben Horowitz, of the venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz, says rap holds lessons for tech entrepreneurs including how to fire an executive or stand up to difficult board members.
articles.abstract: Ben Horowitz, of the venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz, says rap holds lessons for tech entrepreneurs including how to fire an executive or stand up to difficult board members.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — Silicon Valley, where engineers in khakis write software code, might not at first glance have much to do with the world of rap music, where artists in sagging pants write irreverent lyrics.

articles.headline: Vying to Capture Oprah’s Mantle
articles.snippet: Along with current syndicated TV favorites, a multitude of new daytime talk shows will arrive this fall in the first real test for the genre since Oprah Winfrey left the scene in May.
articles.abstract: Along with current syndicated TV favorites, a multitude of new daytime talk shows will arrive this fall in the first real test for the genre since Oprah Winfrey left the scene in May.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is only February, but those in the syndicated television industry care only about September. That is when a multitude of new daytime talk shows will come onto the market, the first real test for the genre since Oprah Winfrey signed off nine months ago.

articles.headline: In China Movie Pact, More 3-D, Less Reality
articles.snippet: A trade agreement between the United States and China expands the number of movie exports, focusing on 3-D or large-screen Imax format extravaganzas.
articles.abstract: A trade agreement between the United States and China expands the number of movie exports, focusing on 3-D or large-screen Imax format extravaganzas.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — More “Mission: Impossible”? Bring it on.

articles.headline: Media Hype for Lin Stumbles on Race
articles.snippet: Jeremy Lin’s hot streak for the Knicks over the past week has threatened the tabloid supply of puns and superlatives, where “Lincredible” was just the beginning.
articles.abstract: Jeremy Lin’s hot streak for the Knicks over the past week has threatened the tabloid supply of puns and superlatives, where “Lincredible” was just the beginning.
articles.lead_paragraph: You don’t have to be an economics graduate from Harvard like Jeremy Lin to do the math on the media explosion about Linsanity.

articles.headline: Pressure, Chinese and Foreign, Drives Changes at Foxconn
articles.snippet: Foxconn Technology’s decision to raise pay at its Chinese factories reflects shifts in China’s economic system.
articles.abstract: Foxconn Technology’s decision to raise pay at its Chinese factories reflects shifts in China’s economic system.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The announcement Saturday that Foxconn Technology — one of the world’s largest electronics manufacturers — will sharply raise salaries and reduce overtime at its Chinese factories signals that pressure from workers, international markets and concerns among Western consumers about working conditions is driving a fundamental shift that could accelerate an already rapidly changing Chinese economy.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Charles Duhigg

articles.headline: After Bailout of Auto Industry, Detroit Fallout Trails Romney
articles.snippet: Whether voters see a principled stand or ruthless capitalism in Mitt Romney’s 2008 opposition to the auto industry rescue will affect how he fares in Michigan’s primary and likely beyond.
articles.abstract: Whether voters see a principled stand or ruthless capitalism in Mitt Romney’s 2008 opposition to the auto industry rescue will affect how he fares in Michigan’s primary and likely beyond.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Congress and the White House scrambled in the fall of 2008 to confront the most severe economic crisis since the Great Depression, Mitt Romney felt compelled to say what many in his native Michigan would consider heresy: Do not bail out the troubled American automakers.

articles.headline: Men Step Out of the Recession, Bag on Hip, Bracelet on Wrist
articles.snippet: Men’s retail sales dropped almost twice as fast as women’s in 2009, but with a jump in accessory sales, the beginning of this year could set a 20-year high for sales growth.
articles.abstract: Men’s retail sales dropped almost twice as fast as women’s in 2009, but with a jump in accessory sales, the beginning of this year could set a 20-year high for sales growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: He’s back.

articles.headline: Iran Raid Seen as a Huge Task for Israeli Jets
articles.snippet: An attack would take at least 100 planes, American defense officials and military analysts said, and take far more time than earlier strikes on nuclear sites in Syria and Iraq.
articles.abstract: An attack would take at least 100 planes, American defense officials and military analysts said, and take far more time than earlier strikes on nuclear sites in Syria and Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Should Israel decide to launch a strike on Iran, its pilots would have to fly more than 1,000 miles across unfriendly airspace, refuel in the air en route, fight off Iran’s air defenses, attack multiple underground sites simultaneously — and use at least 100 planes.

articles.headline: Taliban Gaining More Resources From Kidnapping
articles.snippet: Ransom kidnapping has long been a problem in Pakistan, but the increased involvement by the Taliban and their allies adds a new and disturbing element.
articles.abstract: Ransom kidnapping has long been a problem in Pakistan, but the increased involvement by the Taliban and their allies adds a new and disturbing element.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — A campaign of high-profile kidnappings has provided the Pakistani Taliban and their allies with new resources, arming insurgents with millions of dollars, threatening foreign aid programs and galvanizing a sophisticated network of jihadi and criminal gangs whose reach spans the country.

articles.headline: From Knife Seller to the President’s Hard Edge
articles.snippet: David Plouffe, a senior adviser to President Obama, has asserted himself as the main orchestrator of his political strategy, with a a first-among-equals status in White House’s closed circle.
articles.abstract: David Plouffe, a senior adviser to President Obama, has asserted himself as the main orchestrator of his political strategy, with a a first-among-equals status in White House’s closed circle.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — David Plouffe is not a hugger, crier or someone who gets all gaga every time he walks into his West Wing office, just a few feet from that of the president. He disdains doomsayers as “bed-wetters,” press hordes as “jackals” and the political noise machine as a profanity that begins with “cluster.”
